DOC.brief_title: A Patient-Centered Strategy Improving Diabetes Prevention Urban American Indians
DOC.detailed_description: The goal propose research identify effective patient-centered strategy prevent diabetes high-risk population real world setting . The investigator accomplish conduct randomize controlled trial comparing enhance Diabetes Prevention Program address psychosocial stressor standard version high-risk population urban American Indian Alaskan Native people within primary care set . Diabetes disproportionately prevalent among low-socioeconomic status racial/ethnic minority population US . The high prevalence psychosocial stressor depression , discrimination , exposure trauma among population contributes high prevalence diabetes interferes successful completion lifestyle intervention . The investigator hypothesize DPP directly address psychosocial stressor superior standard DPP address disparity diabetes .
DOC.criteria: Selfidentified urban AIAN men woman BMI Between 3055 Not diagnose Type II Diabetes At least one follow criterion 1 . Triglycerides : 150mg/dL high 2 . Reduced HDL : < 40mg/dL ( men ) ; < 50mg/dL ( woman ) 3 . Blood pressure : > 130/80 current treatment antihypertensives 4 . Fasting glucose : > 100mg/dL Significant medical comorbidities , include uncontrolled metabolic disorder ( e.g. , thyroid , diabetes , renal , liver ) , unstable heart disease , heart failure , ongoing substance abuse ; On great 10 prescription medication . Psychiatric disorder require atypical antipsychotic multiple medication ; Inappropriate moderate exercise accord Revised Physical Activity Readiness Questionnaire ; Pregnant , plan become pregnant , lactate ; Family household member already enrol study ; Already enrol plan enroll clinical trial would limit full participation study ; Resident long term care facility ; Lack speak English patient household member > 18 serve interpreter ; Plans move study period ( 9 month postrandomization ) ; Investigator discretion clinical safety adherence reason ( e.g. , unstable housing , chronic pain ) .
